question: 6 (b)
sols_html:
We saw from part a) that we have the series expansion

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{1}{1+x^3}=1-x^3+x^6-x^9+\ldots\end{aligned}\]

and so we can write that

\[\begin{aligned} \int_0^{0.1} \frac{1}{1+x^3}\,dx &= \int_0^{0.1} dx - \int_0^{0.1} x^3\,dx +\int_0^{0.1} x^6\,dx - \int_0^{0.1} x^9\,dx +\ldots\\ &= 0.1 - \frac{(0.1)^4}{4} + \frac{(0.1)^7}{7} - \frac{(0.1)^{10}}{10} + \ldots\end{aligned}\]

where the nth term is

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{(-1)^n(0.1)^{3n+1}}{3n+1}\end{aligned}\]

Since this is an alternating sequence which converges to zero, we have that the error when neglecting everything past the nth term. Thus

\[\begin{aligned} |\textrm{error}| &\leq \left| \frac{(-1)^n(0.1)^{3n+1}}{3n+1} \right| \\&= \frac{0.1^{3n+1}}{3n+1} \\&= \frac{10^{-(3n+1)}}{3n+1}\end{aligned}\]

if we want this to be less than 10-9, then we can choose n = 3, where the error will be less than

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{10^{(-9+1)}}{9+1}=10^{-11}\end{aligned}\]

which works fine since it is clearly even less than 10-9.

statement_html:
Use part (a) to determine an approximation of the following definite integral

\[\begin{aligned} \int_0^{0.1} \frac{1}{1+x^3}dx\end{aligned}\]

so that the error in the approximation satisfies

\[\begin{aligned} |\text{error}| \leq 10^{-9}\end{aligned}\]

Remember to justify your answer.
